Title.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between disease severity and intervention, patient-valued outcomes, and treatment preferences to inform policy and future research.

Trial_Design.evidence: This prospective cohort study was conducted across 31 National Health Service trusts, involving patients aged >16 years referred for elective surgical treatment of pilonidal disease.

Participants.evidence: involving patients aged >16 years referred for elective surgical treatment of pilonidal disease.

Intervention.evidence: Outcomes were compared between major and minor procedures using regression modeling, propensity score-based approaches, and augmented inverse probability weighting.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between disease severity and intervention, patient-valued outcomes, and treatment preferences to inform policy and future research.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain on days 1 and 7, with secondary outcomes including time to healing, return to normal activities, complications, and recurrence.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 667 patients were included, with 60% undergoing major procedures.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Major procedures resulted in greater pain on day 1 (mean difference 1.58 points, 95% CI 1.14 to 2.01) and day 7 (mean difference 1.53 points, 95% CI 1.12 to 1.95), higher complication rates (adjusted risk difference 17.5%, 95% CI 9.1 to 25.9%), lower recurrence (adjusted risk difference -10.1%, 95% CI -18.1 to -2.1%), and longer recovery times.

Harms.evidence: higher complication rates (adjusted risk difference 17.5%, 95% CI 9.1 to 25.9%)

Funding.evidence: FUNDING: National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: 17/17/02).
